All recommendations from past audits and PHA studies, as well as their implementation status, are included in Intelex or the PSM/RMP/CalARP - Forms / Records Volume.

ms annual internal audits to ensure the site is following the procedures and policies delineated in the facility's PSM/RMP/CalARP programs.  These audits have resulted in recommendations to improve safety at the facility, and the facility has proceeded with addressing and implementing these recommendations.  The facility utilizes a tracking system to ensure the recommendations are addressed in a timely manner.  Below is a sample of action items identified from previous audits that have been completed to improve safety at the facility:

1) Contact the contractor that performs maintenance on the generator. Determine how long the generator is able to supply power to the life safety systems.
Actions Taken: According to the contractor (Power Plus), the tank has a capacity of 300 gallons (100%). At full capacity, the generator will be able to provide power for 20 hours at full load (meaning all equipment attached to the generator). At 150 gallons (50%), the generator will be able to provide power for 10.5 hours at full load.  

2) Create an annual reminder on either Intelex, Master Control, or MS Outlook to invite the fire department onsite to coordinate emergency activities. In addition, utilize the Emergency Response Coordination Form (SHE-EM-103-F-13) to document the invitation and the meeting.
Actions Taken: The last drill was completed on 2/1/2023. The drill recap form was completed to document the drill. The fire department was involved (they came onsite). A rep from the fire department was notified about the drill but dispatch failed to notify fire department personnel so they ended up coming onsite as they thought it was an emergency. The annual reminder was created today on MS Outlook (the reminder pops up on February 1st of each year).

3) Verify that the Contractor Selection Worksheet (SHE-SM-137-F-02) and the SHE Contractor Questionnaire (SHE-SM-137-F-01) have been completed for Siemens.
Actions Taken: The Site Manager emailed the Contractor Selection Workshee

process.  The release must have caused at least one of the following:
1) On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
2) Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

A review of the facility's accident history showed that there have been no releases of regulated substances from the covered processes in the last five years that meet the above criteria.  In addition, there have been no releases of regulated substances that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity for each of the chemicals.

Emergency Response Program

All regulated processes have been identified, located, and mapped. A cylinder storage procedure maintains consistent locations for each material.  Any changes in chemical storage locations are documented with the County of Alameda Department of Environmental Health in the facility's Hazardous Materials Business Plan.

Evacuation procedures have been developed and all personnel are trained in the procedures. In addition, certain employees have been trained to assist the fire department in responding to a release if assistance is needed. The Emergency Response Contact List is maintained and all personnel are trained on the portions relevant to their job.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Matheson Tri-Gas has made enhancements to improve safety at the facility.  For example, the facility has discontinued the use of the boron trichloride and chlorine purification processes, which were previously regulated under CalARP. The systems involved the processing of toxic and corrosive gases.  The chemicals have been removed from the systems, and the equipment has been shut down and properly isolated.  With the systems no longer in service, the likelihood of an accidental release as a result of equipment failure or human factor issues is significantly reduced, thereby improving the safety of the facility and the surrounding community.  

Matheson Tri-Gas perfor

d to identify the engineering and administrative controls in place to detect and mitigate the hazards. Recommendations are generated if the controls are found to be inadequate or non-existent.  These recommendations are then scheduled as process improvements. 

Development and implementation of standard operating procedures: There is a system established for creating, reviewing, and maintaining operating procedures.  Written procedures have been established for the safe handling and storage of gas cylinders.

Development and implementation of accidental release prevention programs and facility safety programs: These programs have been developed in accordance with state and federal regulations.  They are reviewed annually to ensure they are properly implemented and records are maintained to support implementation.

Comprehensive training that includes classroom and on-the-job training:  Training has been established for new and existing employees such that safety in operations is maintained.

A systematic preventive maintenance program: All relevant equipment is on a schedule for inspection. Inspections are documented and certain equipment are tested for proper operation on a regular schedule. 

A thorough accident reporting and investigation program: The accident/incident reporting and investigation procedure requires the reporting and investigation not only of incidents resulting in injuries, but also incidents that had the potential to result in an injury to an employee or a significant impact on the company's business.

Restricted access: The facility has perimeter electronic gates that are always closed to restrict access into the facility. The facility is manned 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. Cameras in the storage areas record all activities.

Five-Year Accident History 

EPA's RMP Program defines accident as the following:

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the

-- Bldg 5 BCl3 Storage
Chlorine ------ Bldg 7 Cl2 Cylinder Storage
Chlorine ------ Bldg 5 Cl2 Cylinder Storage
Hydrogen Chloride ------ Bldg 7 HCl Cylinder Storage
Hydrogen Chloride ------ Bldg 5 HCl Cylinder Storage
Hydrogen Fluoride ------ Bldg 7 HF Cylinder Storage

Trichlorosilane ------ Bldg 5 HSiCl3 Cylinder Storage

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Mitigation Measures

The major elements of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and release mitigation measures at this site are as follows:  

Life safety system: A life safety system was installed in late 1999. This system monitors the presence of various toxic and flammable gases in areas where those gases are stored. Two-stage alarms are set for each sensor. The low-level alarm alerts the facility that a problem may be developing. The high-level alarm triggers an evacuation of the building and provides notification to the Fire Department. The system provides real time readouts of gas concentrations and records all information. This information assists in preventing and mitigating gas releases.  

Adherence to objective equipment standards: One of the most significant contributors to the prevention of accidental releases at this site is the high standard to which all gas cylinders must be manufactured. The Department of Transportation (DOT) and the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) each have detailed requirements for the storage and handling of cylinders. Cylinders must be manufactured according to a particular metallurgical standard and be able to handle an increase in pressure, an increase in temperature, and the possibility that the cylinder will be hit or fall over.     

Process hazard analysis: Process hazard analyses are performed on the regulated processes to determine potential hazards an

Executive Summary:

Note:  This October 2023 update to the RMP was prepared to satisfy the five year update requirement.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Matheson Tri-Gas is committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment, and the procedures necessary to prevent accidental releases of chemicals. In addition, we are committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment and the emergency response procedures necessary to mitigate a release quickly and effectively if it does occur. Employees and management meet regularly to discuss ongoing operations, potential problems, and continuous improvements to prevent releases from occurring. If needed, trained employees can provide assistance to outside emergency responders (fire department) in responding to a release or potential release.  

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Matheson Tri-Gas facility is located at 6775 Central Avenue in Newark, California, which is approximately 1.1 miles southwest of Interstate 880.  The facility stores cylinders of compressed specialty/industrial gas in both large and small quantities. The cylinders vary from 2000 pounds to less than 1 pound of gas, depending on the size of the cylinder and the type of chemical packaged.  The cylinders remain at their respective storage location until purchased by a customer.

There are 10 chemicals in 15 processes at the Matheson Tri-Gas Newark facility that are regulated under the Federal RMP Program.  All regulated processes consist of cylinder storage only.  The detailed applicability of all chemicals, including inventory levels, is listed in the on-site California RMP (CalARP) documentation. The processes regulated under the federal RMP regulations can be summarized as follows:
  
Chemical ------ Process

Ammonia ------ Bldg 7 NH3 Storage
Ammonia ------ Bldg 5 NH3 Storage
Arsine ----- Bldg 7 AsH3 Cylinder Storage
Arsine ----- Bldg 5 AsH3 Cylinder Storage
Boron Trichloride ---
